head.title: ISO observations of the BL Lac object PKS 2155â€“304Based on observations with ISO, an ESA project with instruments funded by ESA Member States (especially the PI countries: France, Germany, the Netherlands and the United Kingdom) with the participation of ISAS and NASA..

meta.content: galaxies: active â€“ BL Lacertae objects: individual: PKS 2155â€“304 â€“ galaxies: photometry â€“ infrared: general

article.h1: ISO observations of the BL Lac object PKS 2155â€“304â€ â€ thanks: Based on observations with ISO, an ESA project with instruments funded by ESA Member States (especially the PI countries: France, Germany, the Netherlands and the United Kingdom) with the participation of ISAS and NASA..

1Osservatorio Astronomico di Brera, via Bianchi 46, Iâ€“23807 Merate (LC), Italy 1
1Osservatorio Astronomico di Brera, via Bianchi 46, Iâ€“23807 Merate (LC), Italy 1
3UniversitÃ dellâ€™Insubria, via Lucini 3, Iâ€“22100 Como, Italy 3

6Osservatorio Astronomico di Brera, via Brera 28, Iâ€“20121 Milano, Italy6

div.p: The BL Lacertae object PKS 2155â€“304 was observed by the Infrared Space Observatory in May and June 1996, during a multiwavelength campaign. These are the first observations in the midâ€“ and farâ€“infrared bands since IRAS. In the observing period, the source showed no detectable time variability at 4.0, 14.3, 60 and 90 Î¼ğœ‡italic-mu\mum. The spectrum from 2.8 to 100 Î¼ğœ‡italic-mu\mum is well fitted by a single power law with energy spectral index Î±=0.4ğ›¼0.4italic-alpha RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.4\alpha=0.4, intermediate between the flatter radio spectrum and the steeper simultaneous optical spectrum. The overall infrared to Xâ€“ray spectral energy distribution can be well explained by optically thin synchrotron emission, with negligible contributions from thermal sources. We also show that the host galaxy flux is negligible in this spectral range.

article.div: Key Words.:galaxies: active â€“ BL Lacertae objects: individual: PKS 2155â€“304 â€“ galaxies: photometry â€“ infrared: general

br.p: BL Lacertae objects are characterized by an intense and variable nonâ€“thermal continuum, that extends from the radio to the gammaâ€“ray band. This is commonly attributed to synchrotron and inverse Compton radiation from a relativistic jet pointing toward the observer (see UlrichMaraschiUrry for a review). In a Î½â¢FÎ½ğœˆsubscriptğ¹ğœˆitalic-nu italic-F POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-nu POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\nu F_{\nu} representation, their overall spectrum has two broad peaks, one at low energies (IRâ€“X) due to synchrotron radiation and one at higher energies (Xâ€“Î³ğ›¾italic-gamma\gamma), plausibly due to inverse Compton scattering.

div.p: PKS 2155â€“304 is one of the brightest BL Lacs from the optical to the Xâ€“ray band with the synchrotron peak in the UV- soft Xâ€“ray range, corresponding to the definition of High frequency peak BL Lac objects (HBL) (PadovaniGiommi ), which have the synchrotron peak at the highest frequencies, low luminosity and a small ratio between the Î³ğ›¾italic-gamma\gammaâ€“ray and the synchrotron peak luminosities. The gamma-ray spectrum is flat (Î±Î³â‰ƒ0.7similar-to-or-equalssubscriptğ›¼ğ›¾0.7italic-alpha POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-gamma POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:similar-to-or-equals NUMBER:0.7\alpha_{\gamma}\simeq 0.7111Î±ğ›¼italic-alpha\alpha is defined as Fâ¢(Î½)âˆÎ½-Î±proportional-toğ¹ğœˆsuperscriptğœˆğ›¼italic-F OPEN:( italic-nu CLOSE:) RELOP:proportional-to italic-nu POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus italic-alpha POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endF(\nu)\propto\nu^{-\alpha}. in the 0.1-10 GeV energy range), indicating that the Compton peak is beyond âˆ¼10similar-toabsent10RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:10\sim 10 GeV. Recently it has been detected in the TeV band (Chadwick et al. Chadwick ). Due to these characteristics, PKSâ€‰2155â€“304 has been the target of numerous multiwavelength campaigns (e.g. Edelson et al.Edelson for November 1991, Urry et al. Urry97 for May 1994). The study of the simultaneous behavior of the source at different frequencies is important in order to understand the emission mechanisms and to constrain the physical properties of the emitting region.

In 1996 Mayâ€“June, an intense multiwavelength monitoring was carried out involving optical telescopes, UV, Xâ€“ray and Î³ğ›¾italic-gamma\gammaâ€“ray satellites. Thanks to the Infrared Space Observatory (ISO), for the first time we had infrared simultaneous observations. These are the first observations of this object in the midâ€“ and farâ€“ infrared since IRAS. PKS 2155â€“304 was detected by IRAS in 1983 at 12, 25, 60 microns with a flux of about 100 mJy in all three bands (Impey & Neugebauer ImpeyNeugebauer ). In this object the IR emission is at frequencies lower than the synchrotron peak, and the spectral shape in this band can reveal if there are relevant thermal contributions (e.g. by the host galaxy or by a dusty torus around the nucleus) or if the emission can be entirely attributed to synchrotron radiation.

Here we present the ISO observations of PKS 2155â€“304, carried out during the campaign in 1996 Mayâ€“June, covering a wavelength range from 2.8 to 200 Î¼ğœ‡italic-mu\mum. This is complemented by some simultaneous BVR observations from the Dutch 0.9 m ESO telescope. Results from ISO observations of 1996 November and 1997 May are also reported.

The paper is organized as follows: a brief description of the ISO instruments and of the observations are given in section 2 and the results are reported in section 3. In section 4 we present the optical data and in section 5 we compare our results with the theoretical models. PKS 2155â€“304 is a weak IR source for ISO. Therefore considerable care was taken in data reduction and background subtraction. Details are given in Appendix A.
PKS 2155â€“304 was observed with ISO between 1996 May 7 and June 8. Two additional observations were performed on 1996 November 23 and 1997 May 15.

The ISO satellite (Kessler ) is equipped with a 60 cm Ritcheyâ€“ChrÃ©tien telescope and has four scientific instruments on board. For the PKS 2155â€“304 observations both the camera ISOCAM and the photometer ISOPHOT were used.

The 32x32 pixel imaging camera ISOCAM (Cesarsky ) has two detectors: an InSb CID (Charge Injection Device) for short wavelengths (SW detector; 2.5 â€“ 5.5 Î¼ğœ‡italic-mu\mum) and a Si:Ga photoconductor array for longer wavelengths (LW detector; 4 â€“ 17 Î¼ğœ‡italic-mu\mum). It is equipped with a set of 21 broadâ€“band filters and a circular variable filter with a higher spectral resolution. The spatial resolution ranges from 1.5â€³â€‰to 12â€³â€‰per pixel.

The photometer ISOPHOT (Lemke ) has three subsystems: a photoâ€“polarimeter (PHTâ€“P) (3 â€“ 120 Î¼ğœ‡italic-mu\mum), which has 3 detectors, sensitive at different wavelengths, 14 broad-band filters and different apertures, from 5â€³â€‰to 180â€³; an imaging photometric camera (PHTâ€“C) (50 â€“ 240 Î¼ğœ‡italic-mu\mum), with a 3x3 and a 2x2 pixel detectors, a field of view of 43.5â€³x43.5â€³â€‰and 89.4â€³x89.4â€³â€‰per pixel, respectively, and 11 broadâ€“band filters; two lowâ€“resolution grating spectrometers (PHTâ€“S) (2.5 â€“ 5 Î¼ğœ‡italic-mu\mum and 6 â€“ 12 Î¼ğœ‡italic-mu\mum).

In order to determine the variability characteristics in the infrared band, 15 identical observations were performed in the period between 1996 May 7 and June 8, at 4.0, 14.3, 60, 90 and 170 Î¼ğœ‡italic-mu\mum (see Tab. 1 for the filter characteristics). From May 13 to May 27 ISO observed PKS 2155â€“304 almost each day. The observing modes (AOTs, Astronomical Observation Templates) were CAM01 (ISOCAMobsman ), in single pointing mode, and PHT22 (ISOPHOTobsman ), in rectangular chopped mode (see Appendix A.2).

figure.figcaption: Table 1: Characteristics of the filters used with ISOCAM and ISOPHOT.

div.p: On 1996 May 27 the source was observed in a large wavelength range (from 2.8 to 200 Î¼ğœ‡italic-mu\mum) with 17 different filters in order to determine the infrared spectrum. The same AOTs as before were used, except the observation with the P2_25 filter, for which the PHT03, still in rectangular chopped mode, was used.

On 1997 May 15 two 3x3 raster scans, centered on PKS 2155â€“304 (R.A. 21h 58m 52s, Dec â€“30Â°â€‰ 13â€²â€‰ 32â€³) were performed with the photometric camera PHTâ€“C, at 60 Î¼ğœ‡italic-mu\mum and at 180 Î¼ğœ‡italic-mu\mum; the distance between two adjacent raster positions was 180â€³, in order to have an almost complete sky coverage of an area of 9â€²â€‰side. This mapping was performed to search for any structure in the cirrus clouds; a non flat background could compromise a reliable photometry of the source. In this observation the AOT PHT22 was used in staring mode.
The ISOPHOT observation of 1996 May 25 failed because of problems during the instrument activation.
The complete log of the observations is shown in Tabs. 2 and 3.

th.span: Note. The integration time of each frame is 2.1 s; the gain is 2.

div.p: The data and the corresponding light curves at 4.0 (SW5 filter), 14.3 (LW3), 60 (C1_60) and 90 Î¼ğœ‡italic-mu\mum (C1_90) are reported in Tabs. 4 and 5 and shown in Figs. 1 and 2. The discussion on the data analysis and error evaluation is given in Appendix A. At 170 Î¼ğœ‡italic-mu\mum (C2_160), the source is not detected: the three sigma upper limit at this wavelength is 1235 mJy (see Fig. 3).

figure.figcaption: Figure 1: ISOCAM light curves of PKS 2155â€“304. The dotted curves represent the fitted constant of the best sampled period, from 1996 May 13 to May 27. The upward arrows are the lower limits in the SW5 curve.
Figure 2: ISOPHOT light curves of PKS 2155â€“304. The dotted curves represent the fitted constant curves of the best sampled period, from 1996 May 13 to May 27.

div.p: When the purpose is to verify whether the flux is variable, the contribution of the pixel responsitivity to the absolute error can be neglected and a smaller uncertainty can be associated to the relative flux values of the light curves. However, this can be done only for the two light curves of the photometer (see Tab. 5), due to the way the photometric error was determined.

The relative errors on the flux are, in any case, quite large, about 10 â€“ 12% for the camera observations and from 20 to more than 50% for the photometer (see Appendix A). Within these uncertainties the light curves show no evidence of variability. To quantify this statement, we fitted the light curves with a constant term and the reduced chiâ€“square values were computed in order to test the goodness of the fits. We first fitted the values of the best sampled period, from 1996 May 13 to May 27. The results are 54.8Â±1.8plus-or-minus54.81.8NUMBER:54.8 ADDOP:plus-or-minus NUMBER:1.854.8\pm 1.8 mJy at 4.0 Î¼ğœ‡italic-mu\mum, 90.8Â±3.2plus-or-minus90.83.2NUMBER:90.8 ADDOP:plus-or-minus NUMBER:3.290.8\pm 3.2 mJy at 14.3 Î¼ğœ‡italic-mu\mum, 315Â±27plus-or-minus31527NUMBER:315 ADDOP:plus-or-minus NUMBER:27315\pm 27 mJy at 60 Î¼ğœ‡italic-mu\mum and 250Â±34plus-or-minus25034NUMBER:250 ADDOP:plus-or-minus NUMBER:34250\pm 34 mJy at 90 Î¼ğœ‡italic-mu\mum. To fit the data at 4.0 Î¼ğœ‡italic-mu\mum the lower limits were neglected. We then repeated the fits, taking the mean of the aboveâ€“mentioned period and adding the other data, to look for possible longerâ€“term variability. All the fits are acceptable within a confidence level of 95%. This means that PKS 2155â€“304 showed no evidence of variability at these wavelengths in the observed period.

However, the large uncertainty on the flux can hide smaller variations. We calculated the mean relative error and obtained 3 sigma limits for the lowest detectable variations of 32%, 36%, 76% and 132% at 4.0, 14.3, 60 and 90 Î¼ğœ‡italic-mu\mum, respectively.

figure.figcaption: Table 6: Fluxes of the observation of 1996 May 27, plus the upper limit at 170 Î¼ğœ‡italic-mu\mum.

figure.figcaption: Figure 3: ISO spectrum. The dashed curve represents the power law fit. Circles are the ISOCAM data; squares are the ISOPHOT data. The horizontal bars indicate the filter width energy response. The upward arrows are the ISOCAM lower limits. The downward arrow at logâ¡Î½âˆ¼12.2similar-toğœˆ12.2OPFUNCTION:logarithm italic-nu RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:12.2\log{\nu}\sim 12.2 is the ISOPHOT upper limit at 170 Î¼ğœ‡italic-mu\mum. Open triangles are the IRAS data (Impey & Neugebauer ImpeyNeugebauer ) at 12, 25 and 60 Î¼ğœ‡italic-mu\mum; the IRAS upper limit at 100 Î¼ğœ‡italic-mu\mum is partially hidden.

div.p: In Fig. 3 it is also shown the result of a power law fit, that gives an energy spectral index of Î±=0.40Â±0.06ğ›¼plus-or-minus0.400.06italic-alpha RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.40 ADDOP:plus-or-minus NUMBER:0.06\alpha=0.40\pm 0.06. The lower and upper limits were not considered in the fit; the reduced chiâ€“square is Ï‡r2=1.31subscriptsuperscriptğœ’2ğ‘Ÿ1.31italic-chi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:1.31\chi^{2}_{r}=1.31, with 9 d.o.f., that gives a confidence level of 77.4%.

From each simultaneous pairs of flux values of the SW5 and LW3 light curves, we obtained the spectral indices between 4.0 and 14.3 Î¼ğœ‡italic-mu\mum as Î±i=-logâ¡(fSâ¢Wâ¢5,i/fLâ¢Wâ¢3,i)/logâ¡(Î½Sâ¢Wâ¢5/Î½Lâ¢Wâ¢3)subscriptğ›¼ğ‘–subscriptğ‘“ğ‘†ğ‘Š5ğ‘–subscriptğ‘“ğ¿ğ‘Š3ğ‘–subscriptğœˆğ‘†ğ‘Š5subscriptğœˆğ¿ğ‘Š3italic-alpha POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals ADDOP:minus OPFUNCTION:logarithm OPEN:( italic-f POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-S italic-W NUMBER:5 PUNCT:, italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide italic-f POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-L italic-W NUMBER:3 PUNCT:, italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) MULOP:divide OPFUNCTION:logarithm OPEN:( italic-nu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-S italic-W NUMBER:5 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide italic-nu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-L italic-W NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)\alpha_{i}=-\log(f_{SW5,i}/f_{LW3,i})/\log(\nu_{SW5}/\nu_{LW3}). The mean value is Î±=0.403Â±0.017ğ›¼plus-or-minus0.4030.017italic-alpha RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.403 ADDOP:plus-or-minus NUMBER:0.017\alpha=0.403\pm 0.017, which is fully consistent with the index derived using 11 filters on a larger IR band.

The fit with a constant term of the spectral indices Î±isubscriptğ›¼ğ‘–italic-alpha POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\alpha_{i} vs. time has a reduced chiâ€“square of 0.26, with 13 d.o.f., which corresponds to a confidence level of less than 1%. This indicates that the source showed no spectral variability in the 4.0 â€“ 14.3 Î¼ğœ‡italic-mu\mum range, during the observed period.

The optical data were obtained using the Dutch 0.9 m ESO telescope at La Silla, Chile, between May 17 and 27 1996. The telescope was equipped with a TEK CCD 512x512 pixels detector and Bessel BVR filters were used for the observations. The pixel size is 27 Î¼ğœ‡italic-mu\mum and the projected pixel size in the plane of the sky is 0.442 arcsec, providing a field of view of 3â€²â€²FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{\prime}.77 x 3â€²â€²FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{\prime}.77.

The original frames were flat fielded and bias corrected using MIDAS package and photometry was performed using the Robin procedure, developed at the Torino Observatory, Italy, by L. Lanteri. This procedure fits the PSF with a circular gaussian and evaluates the background level by fitting it with a 1st order polynomial surface. The magnitude of the object and the error are derived by comparison with reference stars in the same field of view. The typical photometric error is âˆ¼0.02similar-toabsent0.02RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:0.02\sim 0.02 mag in all bands.

The light curves (Tab. 7 and Fig. 4) show an increase of luminosity of about 20% (âˆ¼0.2similar-toabsent0.2RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:0.2\sim 0.2â€“0.250.25NUMBER:0.250.25 mag), between the starting low level of May 17â€“18 and the maximum of May 24. The flux is then decreasing during the last two days. The behavior is very similar in all of the three filters.

Assuming that the optical spectrum is described by a power law, we calculated the mean spectral indices using the simultaneous pairs data of the light curves. The results are Î±Râ¢V=0.62Â±0.02subscriptğ›¼ğ‘…ğ‘‰plus-or-minus0.620.02italic-alpha POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-R italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.62 ADDOP:plus-or-minus NUMBER:0.02\alpha_{RV}=0.62\pm 0.02 and Î±Vâ¢B=0.60Â±0.02subscriptğ›¼ğ‘‰ğµplus-or-minus0.600.02italic-alpha POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-V italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.60 ADDOP:plus-or-minus NUMBER:0.02\alpha_{VB}=0.60\pm 0.02 and indicate that the optical spectrum is steeper than the IR one.

th.span: Note: for all bands uncertainties are âˆ¼0.02similar-toabsent0.02RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:0.02\sim 0.02 mag

figure.figcaption: Figure 4: Optical light curves of PKS 2155â€“304.

div.p: The ISO light curves of Mayâ€“June 1996 show that the time variability of PKS 2155â€“304 in the midâ€“ and farâ€“infrared bands is very low or even absent. The flux has not varied significantly in 1996 November and in 1997 May, one year later, and is quite similar to the 1983 IRAS state (Impey & Neugebauer ImpeyNeugebauer ) (Fig. 3), except at 60 Î¼ğœ‡italic-mu\mum, where the IRAS flux seems significantly lower. This agreement could support the idea that the infrared flux level of this source is rather stable. We have to wait for future satellite missions to test this statement.

The infrared spectrum from 2.8 to 100 Î¼ğœ‡italic-mu\mum is well fitted by a single power law. This is a typical signature of synchrotron radiation, that can explain the whole emission in this wavelength range, excluding important contributions of thermal sources.

The variability in the optical bands is small too, while the simultaneous RXTE light curve (Urry et al. Urry98 , Sambruna ) shows, on the contrary, strong and fast variability at energies of 2â€“20 keV: the flux varied by a factor 2 on a timescale shorter than a day. This seems to be a common behavior in blazars, for which there is a more pronounced variability at frequencies above the synchrotron peak (UlrichMaraschiUrry ).

section.h3: 5.2 Contribution of the host galaxy to the IR flux

div.p: The absence of variability could be also explained by the contribution, in the IR, of a steady component, such as the host galaxy. The host galaxy of PKS 2155â€“304 is a large elliptical which is well resolved in near infrared images (KotilainenFalomoScarpa ), but the pixel field of view of the ISOCAM camera (3â€³or 6â€³) is too big to resolve it and its contribution is integrated in the flux of the active nucleus.

The magnitude of the host galaxy in the Hğ»italic-HH band is mH=12.4subscriptğ‘šğ»12.4italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:12.4m_{H}=12.4 (KotilainenFalomoScarpa ). The color of a typical elliptical at z=0.11ğ‘§0.11italic-z RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.11z=0.11 is B-Hğµğ»italic-B ADDOP:minus italic-HB-H=4.6 (Buzzoni ), from which we get mB=17.0subscriptğ‘šğµ17.0italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:17.0m_{B}=17.0, which corresponds to a flux fBsubscriptğ‘“ğµitalic-f POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:endf_{B} = 0.7 mJy. Mazzei & De Zotti (MazzeiDeZotti ) calculated the flux ratio between the IRAS and the Bğµitalic-BB bands for a sample of 47 elliptical galaxies: their results are logâ¡f12/fB=0.01Â±0.05subscriptğ‘“12subscriptğ‘“ğµplus-or-minus0.010.05OPFUNCTION:logarithm italic-f POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:12 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide italic-f POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.01 ADDOP:plus-or-minus NUMBER:0.05\log{f_{12}/f_{B}}=0.01\pm 0.05, logâ¡f25/fB=-0.70Â±0.32subscriptğ‘“25subscriptğ‘“ğµplus-or-minus0.700.32OPFUNCTION:logarithm italic-f POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:25 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide italic-f POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals ADDOP:minus NUMBER:0.70 ADDOP:plus-or-minus NUMBER:0.32\log{f_{25}/f_{B}}=-0.70\pm 0.32, logâ¡f60/fB=-0.22Â±0.155subscriptğ‘“60subscriptğ‘“ğµplus-or-minus0.220.155OPFUNCTION:logarithm italic-f POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:60 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide italic-f POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals ADDOP:minus NUMBER:0.22 ADDOP:plus-or-minus NUMBER:0.155\log{f_{60}/f_{B}}=-0.22\pm 0.155, logâ¡f100/fB=0.25Â±0.10subscriptğ‘“100subscriptğ‘“ğµplus-or-minus0.250.10OPFUNCTION:logarithm italic-f POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:100 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide italic-f POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.25 ADDOP:plus-or-minus NUMBER:0.10\log{f_{100}/f_{B}}=0.25\pm 0.10. From these relations we can estimate the host galaxy fluxes in the farâ€“IR at 12, 25, 60 and 100 Î¼ğœ‡italic-mu\mum: we have f12=0.7subscriptğ‘“120.7italic-f POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:12 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.7f_{12}=0.7 mJy, f25=0.1subscriptğ‘“250.1italic-f POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:25 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.1f_{25}=0.1 mJy, f60=0.4subscriptğ‘“600.4italic-f POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:60 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.4f_{60}=0.4 mJy, f100=1.2subscriptğ‘“1001.2italic-f POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:100 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:1.2f_{100}=1.2 mJy. If we compare these values with those of Tab. 6, we see that they are less than 1% of the active nucleus flux, and much less than the uncertainties. We thus conclude that the contribution of the host galaxy to the ISO farâ€“IR flux is negligible.

This fact can be also inferred from the spectral energy distribution (SED), built with the simultaneous data of May 1996 (Fig. 5), that shows that the ISO data lie on the interpolation between radio and optical spectra.

figure.figcaption: Figure 5: Spectral energy distribution of PKS 2155â€“304. The black data are the simultaneous data of 1996 May: circles are ISO and BVR fluxes (this paper, data of May 27), and EUVE flux (Marshall H.L., priv. comm.); the Xâ€“ray spectra are from RXTE (Urry et al. Urry98 ); the Î³ğ›¾italic-gamma\gammaâ€“ray upper limit is from EGRET (Vestrand W.T., priv. comm.). Open grey boxes are data from the multiwavelength campaign of 1994 May (Pesce et al. Pesce , Pian et al. Pian , Urry et al. Urry97 ). 1994 ASCA data are from Urry et al. (Urry97 ), 1994 EGRET data are from Vestrand et al. (Vestrand ), 1996 SAX spectrum is from Giommi et al. (Giommi ), 1996 November RXTE spectrum is from Urry et al. (Urry98 ), IRAS data are from Impey & Neugebauer (ImpeyNeugebauer ), Mark 6 point is from Chadwick et al. (Chadwick ).

div.p: The observed IR spectrum is rather flat, and one can wonder if this is due to a partially opaque emission, i.e. if we have, in the IR, the superposition of components with different selfâ€“absorption frequencies, as for the flat radio spectra.

To show that this is nâ¢oâ¢tğ‘›ğ‘œğ‘¡italic-n italic-o italic-tnot the case, we calculate the selfâ€“absorption frequency assuming that the IR radiation originates in the same compact region responsible for most of the emission, including the strongly variable Xâ€“ray flux. This is a conservative assumption, since the more compact is the region, the larger is the selfâ€“absorption frequency. In the case of an isotropic population of relativistic electrons with a powerâ€“law distribution Nâ¢(Î³)=Kâ¢Î³-pğ‘ğ›¾ğ¾superscriptğ›¾ğ‘italic-N OPEN:( italic-gamma CLOSE:) RELOP:equals italic-K italic-gamma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus italic-p POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endN(\gamma)=K\gamma^{-p}, the selfâ€“absorption frequency is given by (e.g. Krolik 1999)

semantics.annotation: italic-nu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-delta italic-nu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:1 ADDOP:plus italic-z ARG:end OPEN:[ FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-p ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-pi italic-square-root ARG:start NUMBER:3 italic-pi ARG:end ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:4 ARG:end FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start Gamma OPEN:( FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:3 italic-p ADDOP:plus NUMBER:22 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:12 ARG:end CLOSE:) Gamma OPEN:( FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:3 italic-p ADDOP:plus NUMBER:2 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:12 ARG:end CLOSE:) Gamma OPEN:( FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-p ADDOP:plus NUMBER:6 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:4 ARG:end CLOSE:) ARG:end ARG:start Gamma OPEN:( FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-p ADDOP:plus NUMBER:8 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:4 ARG:end CLOSE:) ARG:end FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-e italic-tau ARG:end ARG:start italic-B italic-sigma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ARG:end CLOSE:] POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end ARG:start italic-p ADDOP:plus NUMBER:4 ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end PUNCT:,

div.p:
where Î“Î“Gamma\Gamma is the gamma function, Î½Bsubscriptğœˆğµitalic-nu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:end
u_{B} is the cyclotron frequency, Î´ğ›¿italic-delta\delta is the beaming factor, Rğ‘…italic-RR is the size of the source, Ï„â‰¡ÏƒTâ¢Kâ¢Rğœsubscriptğœğ‘‡ğ¾ğ‘…italic-tau RELOP:equivalent-to italic-sigma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-K italic-R	au\equiv\sigma_{T}KR, and pğ‘italic-pp is the slope of the electron distribution appropriate for those electrons radiating at the selfâ€“absorption energy. In the homogeneous synchrotron selfâ€“Compton model, the optical depth Ï„ğœitalic-tau	au is approximately the ratio of the Compton and synchrotron flux at the same frequency. This ratio can be estimated from the SED (Fig. 5), where the Compton flux is obtained by extending at low frequencies the Compton spectrum with the same spectral index of the synchrotron curve. The upper limit for the Î³ğ›¾italic-gamma\gammaâ€“ray emission in 1996 May corresponds to an upper limit for the value of the optical depth of Ï„â‰²10-5less-than-or-similar-toğœsuperscript105italic-tau RELOP:less-than-or-similar-to NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:5 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end	au\lesssim 10^{-5}. From the ISO spectrum, we have p=2â¢Î±+1=1.8ğ‘2ğ›¼11.8italic-p RELOP:equals NUMBER:2 italic-alpha ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1 RELOP:equals NUMBER:1.8p=2\alpha+1=1.8. Although we cannot a priori determine the other two parameters, namely Bğµitalic-BB and Î´ğ›¿italic-delta\delta, a reasonable estimate can be derived through the broad band model fitting. In particular if we adopt the values derived by Tavecchio et al. (Tavecchio ), B=0.25ğµ0.25italic-B RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.25B=0.25 G and Î´âˆ¼30similar-toğ›¿30italic-delta RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:30\delta\sim 30, we get Î½tâ‰²1.4Ã—1011less-than-or-similar-tosubscriptğœˆğ‘¡1.4superscript1011italic-nu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:less-than-or-similar-to NUMBER:1.4 MULOP:times NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:11 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end
u_{t}\lesssim 1.4	imes 10^{11} Hz. For less extreme values of Î´ğ›¿italic-delta\delta, Î½tsubscriptğœˆğ‘¡italic-nu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:end
u_{t} becomes smaller, while much larger values of the magnetic field (making Î½tsubscriptğœˆğ‘¡italic-nu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:end
u_{t} to increase) are implausible, if the significant Î³ğ›¾italic-gamma\gammaâ€“ray emission is due to the selfâ€“Compton process, which requires the source not to be strongly magnetically dominated. The frequency of selfâ€“absorption is thus significantly lower then the IR frequencies, implying that the IR emission is completely thin.

In Fig. 5 we show the SED of PKS 2155â€“304 during our multiwavelength campaign, from the far IR to the Î³ğ›¾italic-gamma\gammaâ€“ray band. We also collected other, not simultaneous, data from the literature, especially in the Xâ€“ray band, to compare our overall spectrum with previous observations. As can be seen, our IR data fill a hole in the SED and, together with our optical results, contribute to a precise definition of the shape of the synchrotron peak. It is remarkable that although the Xâ€“ray state during our campaign was very high (one of the highest ever seen), the optical emission was not particularly bright. Also the upper limit in the Î³ğ›¾italic-gamma\gammaâ€“ray band testifies that the source was not bright in this band.

All this can be explained assuming that the Xâ€“ray flux is due to the steep tail of an electron population distributed in energy as a broken power law. The first part of this distribution is flat and steadier than the high energy, steeper part. In this case without changing significantly the bolometric luminosity large flux variations are possible above the synchrotron (and the Compton) peak. An electron distribution with these characteristics can be obtained by continuous injection and rapid cooling (see e.g. Ghisellini ). In fact, if the electrons are injected at a rate Qâ¢(Î³)âˆÎ³-sproportional-toğ‘„ğ›¾superscriptğ›¾ğ‘ italic-Q OPEN:( italic-gamma CLOSE:) RELOP:proportional-to italic-gamma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus italic-s POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endQ(\gamma)\propto\gamma^{-s} between Î³1subscriptğ›¾1italic-gamma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\gamma_{1} and Î³2subscriptğ›¾2italic-gamma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\gamma_{2}, the steady particle distribution will be Nâ¢(Î³)âˆÎ³-(s+1)proportional-toğ‘ğ›¾superscriptğ›¾ğ‘ 1italic-N OPEN:( italic-gamma CLOSE:) RELOP:proportional-to italic-gamma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus OPEN:( italic-s ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1 CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endN(\gamma)\propto\gamma^{-(s+1)} above Î³1subscriptğ›¾1italic-gamma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\gamma_{1}, and âˆÎ³-2proportional-toabsentsuperscriptğ›¾2RELOP:proportional-to italic-gamma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\propto\gamma^{-2} below, until radiation losses dominate the particle escape or other cooling terms (e.g. adiabatic expansion). Electrons with energy Î³1â¢meâ¢c2subscriptğ›¾1subscriptğ‘šğ‘’superscriptğ‘2italic-gamma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-e POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-c POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\gamma_{1}m_{e}c^{2} are the ones responsible for the emission at the synchrotron and Compton peaks (as long as the scattering process is in the Thomson limit). Since it is possible to change sğ‘ italic-ss without changing the total injected power, large flux variations above the peak are compatible with only minor changes below. This model also predicts that the spectrum below the peak has a slope Î±=0.5ğ›¼0.5italic-alpha RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.5\alpha=0.5, which is not far from what we have observed in the far IR.

section.div: Acknowledgements. We would like to thank the ISOCAM team and, in particular, Marc Sauvage for his help with CIA, the ISOCAM data reduction procedure and with the installation of the software at OAB. We also thank Giuseppe Massone e Roberto Casalegno, who made the optical observations at La Silla.

div.p: The observations were processed with CIA222ISOCAM Interactive Analysis, CIA, is a joint development by the ESA Astrophysics Division and the ISOCAM Consortium led by the ISOCAM PI, C. CÃ©sarsky, Direction des Sciences de la MatiÃ¨re, C.E.A., France. v2.0.
Each observation consisted in a sequence of frames, which had an elementary integration time of about 2 s. By this way the temporal behaviour of each pixel was known.
First, the dark current was subtracted from each raw frame, using the dark images present in the software library, flagging the bad pixels of SW and LW detectors.

The impact of charged particles (glitches) on the detectors create spikes in the pixel signal curve. To remove these spurious signals, we first used the Multiresolution Median Transform method (Starck ), then every frame was inspected to make sure that the number of suppressed noise signals was negligible and finally a manual deglitching operation was done to detect the glitches left and flag them. Some glitches caused a change in the pixel sensitivity: in this case we flagged the pixel in all readouts after the glitch.

The library dark images were not good enough to remove all the effects of the dark current: the signals in rows and columns showed a sawâ€“teeth structure, that was eliminated using the Fast Fourier Transform technique (StarckPantin ).

The response of the detector pixels to a change in the incident flux is not immediate and the signal reaches the stabilization after some time. This time interval depends on the initial and final flux values and on the number of readouts (ISOCAMobsman ). Therefore, the time sequence of a pixel signal shows, after a change in the incident flux, an upward or downward transient behaviour. At the beginning of every observation, after a certain number of frames, the signal should reach the stable value. As this ideal situation could not always been achieved, CIA provides different routines to overcome this problem and apply the transient correction. These routines use different models to fit the signal curves, in order to identify the stable value.

In the SW5 observations, the photons coming from PKS 2155â€“304 fell mainly in one or two pixels, whose signals showed an upward transient behaviour that never reached the stabilization. On the contrary, the background, being very low, was stabilized. No transient correction routines were able to adequately fit the source signals, either underestimating or overestimating the stable flux. Observing the signal curves, we noticed that the behaviour of the first part of the curves were far from the expected converging trends that are used in the models of the correction routines, while the remaining part of the curves seemed to be well described by a converging exponential trend. So, after having discarded the starting readouts, we fitted the signal with a simple exponential model sfâ¢iâ¢t=sâˆ+câ‹…e-t/Ï„subscriptğ‘ ğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘ â‹…ğ‘superscriptğ‘’ğ‘¡ğœitalic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-f italic-i italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ID:infinity POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus italic-c MULOP:cdot italic-e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus italic-t MULOP:divide italic-tau POSTSUPERSCRIPT:ends_{fit}=s_{\infty}+c\cdot e^{-t/\tau}, where the optimized parameters are cğ‘italic-cc, Ï„ğœitalic-tau\tau and sâˆsubscriptğ‘ italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ID:infinity POSTSUBSCRIPT:ends_{\infty}, that represents the stable signal. We chose the fit which showed a reasonable result and optimized the determination coefficient R2=1-âˆ‘i(si-sfâ¢iâ¢t)2âˆ‘i(si-sÂ¯)2superscriptğ‘…21subscriptğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ ğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘¡2subscriptğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘–Â¯ğ‘ 2italic-R POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:1 ADDOP:minus FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start SUMOP:sum POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-f italic-i italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end ARG:start SUMOP:sum POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-s ARG:end CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:endR^{2}=1-\frac{\sum_{i}(s_{i}-s_{fit})^{2}}{\sum_{i}(s_{i}-\bar{s})^{2}}, where sisubscriptğ‘ ğ‘–italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:ends_{i} are the measured signals and sÂ¯Â¯ğ‘ OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-s ARG:end\bar{s} is the mean of the part we considered. In three cases, the results were not acceptable and we could define only lower limits, as the upward transients had not reached the stabilization.

For the transient correction of the LW3 observations, the model developed at the Institut dâ€™Astrophysique Spatiale (IAS Model) (AbergelDesertAussel ) has been used. As the corrected curves attained stable values in the second half only, we did not use the first half of the frames.

In the spectral observation of May 27, the uninterrupted sequence of filters used created either upward or downward transients and the stabilization of the source signal was reached just in few cases. The five observations made with the SW channel were corrected using the same method as the SW5 ones, except for the SW11 filter, in which the stabilization was reached for all pixels. In this case, we just discarded the first half of the 162 frames. In the SW2 filter data, at the end of the observation, the source signal was so far from stabilization that we could define only a lower limit. The five observations made with the LW channel were corrected using the IAS model. As this model takes into account all the past illumination history, we fitted a unique curve that was built linking together all the LW filters data. This method worked fine for two filters only (LW8 and LW9), while for the other three filters again we defined lower limits.
We averaged all the frames neglecting the flagged signal values and then the images were flat fielded, using the library flat fields of CIA.

The total signal of the source was computed integrating the values of the signal in a box centered on the source and subtracting the normalized background obtained in a ring of 1 pixel width around the box. The boxes had dimension ranging from 3x3 to 7x7 pixels, depending on the filter and on the pixel field of view (pfov). The results were colour corrected and divided for the point spread function (PSF) fraction falling in the box. This fraction also depends on filters and pfov. To compute it, we extracted from the library, for each combination of filter and pfov, the nine PSF images centered more or less on the same pixels of PKS 2155â€“304. For calibration requirements, in each PSF image the centroid of the source was placed in a slightly different position inside the same pixel. As we do not know with enough accuracy the position of the centroid of PKS 2155â€“304 in the ISOCAM images, the nine PSF were averaged and the result was normalized. The PSF correction was calculated by summing the signal of the pixels in a box of the same dimension of that in which we extracted the source signal. For the LW detector, a further correction factor was applied to take into account the flux of the pointâ€“like source that falls outside the detector (Okumura ). For the SW channel, we adopted for all filters the SW5 PSF, because, along with SW1, was the only one present in the calibration library, however the error we introduced can only be of a few percent.
Finally, the source signal was converted to flux density using the coefficients in Blommaert (Blommaert ).

To compute the photometric error we divided the uncertainty sources in two parts: the first one took into account the dark current subtraction, deglitching, flat fielding operations and signal to flux conversion, while the second one considered the transient correction. The first group of error sources are derived from the Automatic Analysis Results (AAR; OLP v7.0 for the light curves data, OLP v6.3.2 for the spectrum data). The source flux values fAâ¢Aâ¢Rsubscriptğ‘“ğ´ğ´ğ‘…italic-f POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-A italic-A italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:endf_{AAR} given by the AAR are not reliable because the transient correction is not performed, but the AAR absolute flux errors ÏƒAâ¢Aâ¢Rsubscriptğœğ´ğ´ğ‘…italic-sigma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-A italic-A italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\sigma_{AAR} are a good estimate of the first group of errors (the AAR fluxes are given in Tabs. 4 and 6). We assumed that the fluxes fsâ¢râ¢csubscriptğ‘“ğ‘ ğ‘Ÿğ‘italic-f POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-s italic-r italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:endf_{src} that we derived have the same relative error Ïƒrâ¢eâ¢l=ÏƒAâ¢Aâ¢R/fAâ¢Aâ¢Rsubscriptğœğ‘Ÿğ‘’ğ‘™subscriptğœğ´ğ´ğ‘…subscriptğ‘“ğ´ğ´ğ‘…italic-sigma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-r italic-e italic-l POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-sigma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-A italic-A italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide italic-f POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-A italic-A italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\sigma_{rel}=\sigma_{AAR}/f_{AAR}. Thus, for our fluxes this part of error is Ïƒf=Ïƒrâ¢eâ¢lâ¢fsubscriptğœğ‘“subscriptğœğ‘Ÿğ‘’ğ‘™ğ‘“italic-sigma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-f POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-sigma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-r italic-e italic-l POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-f\sigma_{f}=\sigma_{rel}\,f, which accounts for all the uncertainties sources, but the transient correction. We estimated that the error due to the transient correction is of the order of 10%, which is the rounded maximum error on the stable signal sâˆsubscriptğ‘ italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ID:infinity POSTSUBSCRIPT:ends_{\infty}, obtaining a total error of Ïƒ=Ïƒf2+Ïƒtâ¢r2ğœsubscriptsuperscriptğœ2ğ‘“subscriptsuperscriptğœ2ğ‘¡ğ‘Ÿitalic-sigma RELOP:equals italic-square-root ARG:start italic-sigma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-f POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus italic-sigma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-t italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ARG:end\sigma=\sqrt{\sigma^{2}_{f}+\sigma^{2}_{tr}}. We assumed then a Ïƒtâ¢rsubscriptğœğ‘¡ğ‘Ÿitalic-sigma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-t italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\sigma_{tr} of 10% for all our measurements (20% for SW4 and SW10 filters).

The observations were done in rectangular chopped mode: the observed field of view switches alternately between the source and an 180â€³â€‰distant offâ€“source position. This is necessary in order to measure the background level. The chopping direction was along the satellite Z-axis, which was slowly rotating by about one degree per day. Thus, every time the background was sampled in different fields of the sky and a raster map was performed just to check the stability of the background all around the source. The standard deviation of the background flux measured in the central pixel of the C100 detector, in the eight off-source positions of the scan, is 37 mJy. This value is much less than the error of the source flux (see Tab. 5). This small background fluctuation would lead to a rise of the scatter of the source flux, in any case our results are compatible with absence of variability (see section 3).

Each observation of an astronomical target was immediately followed by a Fine Calibration Source (FCS) measurement, using internal calibrations sources. These measurements were made in order to determine the detector responsitivity, which is necessary to compute the target flux.
Each observation consisted in a series of integration ramps, each one made by the sequence of voltage readouts between two destructive readouts.

The observations were processed with PIA333ISOPHOT Interactive Analysis (PIA) is a joint development by the ESA Astrophysics Division and the ISOPHOT Consortium. The ISOPHOT Consortium is led by the Maxâ€“Planckâ€“Institute for Astronomy, Heidelberg. v7.0 (Gabriel ).

PIA separates the operations to be performed on the data in different levels: at each level PIA creates a data structure on which it operates. This data structure takes its name according to the properties of the data. The first part of the data analysis was common for all the observations, then the procedures changed according to the different characteristics of the observation (whether it was chopped or not or whether the detector was receiving photons from the astronomical target or from the FCS).

At the beginning, PIA automatically converted the digital data from telemetry in meaningful physical units and created the structure of data, called Edited Raw Data (ERD). At the ERD level, some starting readouts and the last readout of each ramp were discarded, because they are disturbed by the voltage resetting; we also manually discarded the part of the ramp before or after a glitch (that causes a sudden jump of the readout value) in the cases where most part of the ramp was unchanged and the glitch did not modify the detector responsitivity. A correction for the nonâ€“linear responsitivity of the detector was applied, using special calibration files. Then, each ramp was fitted by a 1st order polynomial model. A signal (in V s-11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-1}) was obtained from the slope of every ramp: the slope is proportional to the incident power. At Signal per Ramp Data (SRD) level, the first half of the signals per chopper plateau were discarded, because of stabilization problems. As the signal value depends on the integration time, a correction factor was applied and the signal was normalized for an integration time of 1/4 s. The dark current was subtracted using the PIA calibration files, which take into account the satellite position in the orbit. An algorithm was applied to discover and discard the signals that were anomalously high, because of glitches; then, the signals of each chopper plateau were averaged. At Signal per Chopper Plateau (SCP) level, the responsitivity of each detector pixel was computed taking the median of the FCS2 signals of the calibration measurements; then, the vignetting correction was performed on the target observations. In the chopped measurements, the background, that was calculated at the offâ€“source position, was subtracted to get the source signal.

As for the camera, the response of the photometer detectors has some delays after a change in the incident flux. This effect causes losses in the signal values measured in the chopped measurements, so a correction factor was applied. The signal was finally converted into power, using the responsitivity obtained from the FCS measurement.

In the observations performed with the 3x3 pixel C100 detector, only the central pixel was used to compute the source flux density, because, as the most of the Airy disk of a point-like source centered in the pixel lies in the same pixel (69% for C1_60 and 61% for C1_90), to use the outer pixels just adds more noise than signal. The source flux density is defined as FÎ»=Psâ¢râ¢c/(Câ¢1â¢fpâ¢sâ¢f)subscriptğ¹ğœ†subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘ ğ‘Ÿğ‘ğ¶1subscriptğ‘“ğ‘ğ‘ ğ‘“italic-F POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-P POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-s italic-r italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide OPEN:( italic-C NUMBER:1 italic-f POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-p italic-s italic-f POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)F_{\lambda}=P_{src}/(C1f_{psf}), where Psâ¢râ¢csubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘ ğ‘Ÿğ‘italic-P POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-s italic-r italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:endP_{src} is the incident power, Câ¢1ğ¶1italic-C NUMBER:1C1 is a conversion factor of each filter (as given in the PIA calibration file pfluxconv.fits) and fpâ¢sâ¢fsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘ğ‘ ğ‘“italic-f POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-p italic-s italic-f POSTSUBSCRIPT:endf_{psf} is the fraction of PSF that falls on the pixel considered when the source is located in the centre (ISOPHOTobsman , Tabs. 2 and 4).

The absolute photometric error was computed by PIA, during the data reduction process, and took into account the uncertainty in the determination of the slope of the ramp and the errors associated to the other performed correction operations.
